video.title: Statistics - A Full University Course on Data Science Basics
video.description:
Learn the essentials of statistics in this complete course. This course introduces the various methods used to collect, organize, summarize, interpret and reach conclusions about data. An emphasis is placed on demonstrating that statistics is more than mathematical calculations. By using examples gathered from real life, students learn to use statistical methods as analytical tools to develop generalizations and meaningful conclusions in their field of study. 

🎥 Course by Monika Wahi.
🔗 These lectures are based on the textbook Understanding Basic Statistics, 6th Edition, by Brase & Brase, available here: https://www.amazon.com/Understanding-Basic-Statistics-Charles-Henry/dp/1111827028
🔗 Monika Wahi's LinkedIn Learning courses are here: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/instructors/monika-wahi?u=2125562
🔗 Visit Monika Wahi's web page here: http://www.dethwench.com/
🔗 Monika Wahi's peer-reviewed articles listed here: https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=v3BDf1oAAAAJ&hl=en

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) What is statistics
⌨️ (0:33:34) Sampling
⌨️ (1:21:20) Experimental design
⌨️ (2:00:32) Randomization
⌨️ (2:16:25) Frequency histogram and distribution
⌨️ (2:35:58) Time series, bar and pie graphs
⌨️ (3:10:10) Frequency table and stem-and-leaf
⌨️ (3:39:41) Measures of central tendency
⌨️ (4:11:56) Measure of variation
⌨️ (4:58:35) Percentile and box-and-whisker plots
⌨️ (5:24:58) Scatter diagrams and linear correlation
⌨️ (6:39:54) Normal distribution and empirical rule
⌨️ (7:05:39) Z-score and probabilities
⌨️ (7:45:11) Sampling distributions and the central limit theorem

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: sathyesh 4511
topLevelComment.text: Is randomization and simple random sample same?

replies.author: Monika Wahi
replies.text: You make an interesting observation! They have a similarity, but they are for different things. Simple random sampling is for choosing who to invite into your study in the first place (some may say "no", and some might not be eligible). Once they get in, randomization is what you use to put them in different treatment groups.

topLevelComment.author: Ebiru2387
topLevelComment.text:
I have a question about the usage of N vs n.  In my job directors are assigned certain accounts.  I often see reports run for their division where we include ALL of their accounts within that division.  In those reports, if we are focusing EXCLUSIVELY on all accounts within the division, would we refer to that data as the population(N) or the sample(n)?   

I would be inclined to refer to them as a sample, but because the scope of these reports are ONLY on this division, i could see an argument for referring to this group as a population because our scope includes ALL ACCOUNTS in this division and ONLY this division.

Any thoughts?  Thank you in advance :)

topLevelComment.author: Dominic Jung
topLevelComment.text:
I like how this lecture tried to disseminate hard and alienating subject of statistics in easier ways. I feel like statistics that are delivered through university platforms are usually quite messy and not very organized because, unlike calculus or engineering math subjects, statistics materials are very different from books to books and lectures to lectures.

For example for simple topics like regression, the way some lectures explain the formula are just nightmares. Without clear explanation some lectures decide to divide some values for convenience during calculation, or use confusing names like SS, RSS for the same thing and mix naming conventions for vector, and elements of vectors while traversing through them to calculate cost functions etc.

Statistics is useful, no doubt about that, but with the way they are taught in many of universities, I also got to hate statistic subjects although I did have great interests in other math and physics subjects.

replies.author: Federica D.L.
replies.text:
I don't know if you still need this a month later, but here's what I got from it.

We want to find the scores that mark the middle 20% of the data (10% on each side of the middle line that separates the two halves of the distribution).
20% (20 out of 100) is the same as saying 0.2000 (0.2 out of 1).
The whole area under the curve is 1 (or 100%). You only want the middle 0.2000 (or 0.1000 on each side of the central line).
The area you do NOT want is the entire area (1) minus the area of interest (0.2000). Divide that by 2 so you can focus on the first half of the distribution. This way you obtain 0.4000.
You could obtain the exact same result by considering half of the whole area (1/2 = 0.5000) and subtracting 0.1000 from it.

In order words, 0.4000 represents the first part of the area that you do NOT want to consider. When you find the z-score for 0.4000 and convert it to x, you'll find the lower limit of your interval (the lower score that marks the middle 20% of the data). Below that limit lies the 40% that you do NOT want to consider.
For the upper limit, you can do the exact same thing on the other half of the area (in this case the z-score will be the opposite). Above that limit lies the 40% that you do NOT want to consider.
In between 

Hope this helps!

PS: I suggest you also have a look at her graph while going through this, I find it makes a lot more sense when you visualize things.

topLevelComment.text:
On a side note, I hate the 5 star rating system because you can't rate less than 1 star. So, it's kind of like a 4 star system, except people rating or using the ratings to make their decisions don't necessarily all see the ratings equally. 

The lower the rating, the more confusion. In a 0 to 5 scale, 1 star = 20%, while in a 1 to 5 scale 0 = to 0%. While in a 0 tp 5 scale, a 4.5 means 90%, while in a 1 to 5 scale 4.5 means 85%.

To make it clear, the 5 star rating system should start a 0.

replies.author: paul barton
replies.text: @ParadymShift, Plant-BASED Ⓥegan Jedi it depends. I've noticed that concerning IT or software development you are right, experience wins, but no one is getting hired in applied math without a degree. I'm talking about statistics, operations research, industrial engineering, even machine learning engineering, stuff like that. I think employers want to see some kind of STEM degree along with some experience. Try to self teach yourself bio-informatics and see if you get an interview.

replies.author: paul barton
replies.text: @Invisible Babyface Thats cool you got a help desk job without the degree, I support self-learning, but for the most part people are looking at statistics so they can get into business analytics, data science, machine learning. Companies don't want self-taught analysts making million dollar business decisions any more than hospitals want self-taught surgeons doing surgery. Now having 10-15 years of IT/programming experience and then learning the math, they might trust you, but just trying to get a foot in the door in analytics with no degree whatsoever is not easy.
